sections.content: Rati is the Hindu goddess of passion, sexual desire, and carnal pleasure. As the divine consort of Kamadeva, the god of love, she embodies the blissful and intoxicating aspects of romantic and physical attraction. Her name literally means 'pleasure' or 'delight' in Sanskrit, reflecting her fundamental nature as the personification of desire fulfilled.
sections.title: Description

sections.content: According to the Shiva Purana and other texts, Rati was created by Brahma from his mind, emerging as the most beautiful woman in creation. Her beauty was so overwhelming that she caused desire to awaken in all beings. She was given as wife to Kamadeva, and together they became the divine embodiment of love and passion working in harmony.
sections.title: Divine Origin

sections.content: The most significant myth involving Rati concerns the death and resurrection of her husband Kamadeva. When Kama disturbed Shiva's meditation by shooting his flower arrows to awaken desire for Parvati, the enraged Shiva opened his third eye and reduced Kamadeva to ashes. Rati's grief was immeasurable - her lamentations moved even the gods. Through her devoted prayers, penances, and the intercession of Parvati, Kamadeva was eventually restored, though he remained bodiless (Ananga) until reborn as Pradyumna, son of Krishna and Rukmini. Rati was herself reborn as Mayavati to reunite with him.
sections.title: The Burning of Kamadeva

name: Rati

attributes.weapons: Beauty, seduction, the power of desire

listDisplay.primary: Rati - Goddess of Passion and Desire
listDisplay.secondary: The divine consort of Kamadeva, Rati embodies passion, pleasure, and the fulfillment of desire in Hindu mythology.
listDisplay.expandedContent: Rati is the Hindu goddess of passion, carnal pleasure, and sexual love. Born from the mind of Brahma as the most beautiful woman in creation, she became the eternal consort of Kamadeva, the god of love. Her devotion to her husband is legendary - when Shiva reduced Kamadeva to ashes, Rati's grief and subsequent penances led to his eventual restoration.

title: Rati - Hindu Goddess of Passion
description: Rati is the Hindu goddess of passion, sexual desire, and carnal pleasure. As the divine consort of Kamadeva, the god of love, she embodies the blissful and intoxicating aspects of romantic and physical attraction. Her name literally means 'pleasure' or 'delight' in Sanskrit. Born from Brahma's mind as the most beautiful woman in creation, Rati represents desire fulfilled and the transformative power of devotion through her role in Kamadeva's death and resurrection.

hoverInfo.quick: Hindu goddess of passion and desire, eternal consort of Kamadeva the god of love.

summary: Rati is the Hindu goddess of passion, sexual desire, and carnal pleasure. As the eternal consort of Kamadeva (the god of love), she embodies fulfilled desire and the transformative power of devotion. Her story of grief and perseverance following Kamadeva's destruction by Shiva demonstrates the Hindu concept that true love transcends even death.

relationships.children: Harsha (Joy) and Yashas (Grace) in some traditions

mythsAndLegends.title: The Creation of Rati
mythsAndLegends.summary: Brahma created Rati from his mind as the most beautiful woman in existence. Her beauty was so extraordinary that it awakened desire in all beings. She was given to Kamadeva as his wife, and together they became the divine couple embodying love and passion.

mythsAndLegends.title: The Burning of Kamadeva
mythsAndLegends.summary: When Kamadeva shot his flower arrows at Shiva to awaken his desire for Parvati, the ascetic god opened his third eye and reduced Kama to ashes. Rati's grief was profound and her lamentations moved heaven and earth.

mythsAndLegends.title: Rati's Devotion and Kamadeva's Restoration
mythsAndLegends.summary: Through devoted prayers, penances, and Parvati's intercession, Kamadeva was eventually restored, though initially in bodiless (Ananga) form. Some texts say he was fully restored after Shiva's marriage to Parvati.

mythsAndLegends.title: Rebirth as Mayavati
mythsAndLegends.summary: In one tradition, Rati was reborn as Mayavati while Kamadeva was reborn as Pradyumna, son of Krishna and Rukmini. Mayavati raised Pradyumna and later revealed their true identities, reuniting the divine lovers.

corpusQueries.description: Primary search for Rati as goddess of passion

worship.temples: Worshipped alongside Kamadeva; no exclusive temples but honored in love/fertility shrines
festivals: Holi (Festival of colors - associated with Kamadeva)
worship.offerings: Red flowers, sandalwood, mango blossoms, incense
worship.practices: Invoked for romantic love, marital harmony, and fertility

iconography.appearance: Depicted as an extraordinarily beautiful young woman, often with her husband Kamadeva
iconography.attributes: Carries lotus flowers, sometimes shown with a parrot
iconography.colors: Red, pink, gold - colors of passion and love
iconography.posture: Often shown in graceful, alluring poses befitting a goddess of desire
